Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Applying the AGO Network to Energy Transfer in the Radiation Belts and Remote Sensing of Auroral Plasma Processes
Award.AbstractNarration: With this award, researchers at Dartmouth College and Stanford University will be addressing outstanding scientific questions regarding the energy transfer in the Earth's radiation belts and auroral plasma physics. Energetic plasma interacting with the geomagnetic field in the near-Earth space (geospace) environment emits electromagnetic waves across the radio spectrum, and ground-based measurements of these waves are used as diagnostic tools to investigate various processes in geospace. This investigation takes advantage of an existing network of radio receivers located in Antarctica from -70 to -85 degrees of invariant geomagnetic latitude and operating in the frequency range from extra low to high frequencies (ELF ~300 Hz to HF ~5 MHz). The Antarctic continent is ideally suited for these types of natural radio wave experiments since it is largely devoid of anthropogenic electromagnetic interference such as power line harmonics and radio frequency broadcast transmissions. The project will focus on studies of three geophysically important plasma waves. The first, chorus wave is believed to be a major driver of radiation belt electron acceleration and loss. The other two waves, auroral hiss and auroral kilometric radiation (AKR), are generated in the auroral acceleration region and have the potential to be used for remote sensing of this complex and poorly understood near-Earth region. The proposed studies are motivated by a recent, exciting detection of AKR on the Earth?s surface which was unexpected since the currently accepted theory for these waves generation predicts beaming of the radiation only outward away from Earth. This research also contributes to the training and education of both the young scientists and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At Dartmouth College, this grant supported two master's degree recipients, Xi Yan and Howard Kim, and partially supported two PhD recipients, Matt Broughton and Micah Dombrowski. All successfully completed their degrees and entered the workforce.Five Dartmouth undergraduates also obtained training and research experience contributing to the work of this grant.

Yan analyzed Stanford and Dartmouth radio data from South Pole Station, focussing on natural radio emissions from aurora called auroral hiss. These are significant because they mark the onset of polar substorms, the major pattern of energy release in the aurora.Yan's work identified different types of hiss associated with different times of day of occurrence.

Kim analyzed Stanford radio data for structures called "hisslers" imbedded in the auroral hiss emissions, using for the first time a statistical approach to characterizing this phenomenon and correcting misleading statements in previous literature.

Broughton identified a new, rare type of auroral radio emission observed
at South Pole Station. Dombrowski contributed to both hardware and software aspects of instrumentation deployed at South Pole Station and at the Automatic Geophysical Observatories (AGOs).

Dartmouth PI James LaBelle led follow-up observations of unusual occurrences of auroral kilometric radiation (AKR) seen at ground level, including the first polarization measurements of these emissions, showing them to be right-hand polarized, and the first high resolution measurements showing that they have fine structure very similar to that  of AKR observed in space. AKR is important because it is the most powerful natural radio emission from Earth and results from a mechanism that produces similar powerful radio emissions from all the other magnetized planets such as Jupiter and Saturn. It has long been thought that AKR can only be observed in space, beamed away from Earth. Recent evidence from South Pole Station contradicts that scenario by showing that AKR can penetrate to ground-level.
